questions.text: 30/male, k/c/o DM + HTN + Obesity presented to the casualty with fever and cough for 3 days. RT-PCR for COVID-19 was positive. SpO2 in casualty was 93%. The patient was admitted in view of moderate COVID-19 and comorbidities. The patient was started on low-flow O2. However, on day 3 of admission, the patient developed acute breathlessness and SpO2 dropped to 85%. Patient shifted to the ICU and was put on NIV with FiO2 60% and low pressures. SpO2 then improved to 94%. ABG done showed paO2 of 90mmHg, paCO2 40 mmHg, and HCO3 of 24 mmol/L. Which of the following represents the histologic feature of this patient, had his lungs been autopsied ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse Alveolar Damage The given case scenario is of COVID-19 ARDS . The diagnosis of ARDS can be made by paO2/FiO2 of 150 in this case. The peculiar feature of COVID-19 ARDS is that it improves with O2 therapy. ARDS should be suspected in patients with progressive symptoms of dyspnea, an increasing requirement for oxygen, and alveolar infiltrates on chest imaging within 6 to 72 hours of an inciting event. A Characteristic histologic feature of COVID-19 ARDS is Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD) In ARDS, damage occurs to Type 1 pneumocytes, while Type 2 pneumocytes are responsible for regeneration as they behave like progenitors of Type 1 pneumocytes. Goblet cells and ciliated epithelium are found in tracheobronchial tree and larger bronchi and absent in alveoli.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, and D - UIP , Bronchiolitis and pneumonia - these all are basically chronic conditions and will not present in this clinical case.

Highyeild:

Clinical diagnosis (Berlin definition) : ARDS can be diagnosed once cardiogenic pulmonary edema and alternative causes of acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, and bilateral infiltrates have been excluded. The Berlin Definition of ARDS requires that all of the following criteria be present for diagnosis: Respiratory symptoms must have begun within one week of a known clinical insult, or the patient must have had new or worsening symptoms during the past week. Bilateral opacities must be present on a chest radiograph or computed tomographic (CT) scan. These opacities must not be fully explained by pleural effusions, lobar collapse, lung collapse, or pulmonary nodules. The patient's respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. An objective assessment (e.g., echocardiography) to exclude hydrostatic pulmonary edoema is required if no risk factors for ARDS are present. A moderate to severe impairment of oxygenation must be present, as defined by the ratio of arterial oxygen tension to the fraction of inspired oxygen ( PaO 2 /FiO 2 ). The severity of the hypoxemia defines the severity of the ARDS: Mild ARDS – The PaO2/FiO2 is >200 mmHg, but ≤300 mmHg, on ventilator settings that include positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) ≥5 cm H 2 O. Moderate ARDS – The PaO2/FiO2 is >100 mmHg, but ≤200 mmHg, on ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H 2 O. Severe ARDS – The PaO2/FiO2 is ≤100 mmHg on ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H 2 O.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A:- Acute onset Option B:- Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on CXR Option C:- PCWP < 18 mmHg Option D:- PaO2/FiO2 < 200

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding ARDS management 1. Steroids may be beneficial in fat embolism 2. Nutrition supplement with high fat and antioxidant is beneficial 3. Overall mortality is 50-75% 4. Stress ulcer might be complication of ET intubation Pick out the correct option:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TTTT All the options are correct. Corticosteroids reduced the risk of FES by 78% (95% confidence interval [CI] 43%–92%), and that only 8 patients needed to be treated (95% CI 5–13 patients) to prevent 1 case of FES. Similarly, corticosteroids significantly reduced the risk of hypoxia. Vocal fold ulcers are well-known complications of prolonged intubations. Mucosal damage during intubation, larger tube size, infection, and the clasping movements between the vocal cords and the tube along with the continuous tube pressure are among the main causes of vocal cord ulcers.

questions.text: A 62 year old alcoholic male is hospitalized with severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting.Serum amylase and lipase are elevated. During hospitalization his condition deteriorates and he develops severe respiratory distress. There are crackles bilaterally on auscultation and infiltrates bilaterally on chest x ray.The patient fails to respond to mechanical ventilation and 100%oxygen,and dies soon because of respiratory insufficiency.Which of the following autopsy findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alveolar hyaline membrane The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis which is a major risk factor for ARDS. ARDS is characterized by hypoxemia refractory to oxygen therapy, decreased lung compliance,interstitial edema progressing to diffuse alveolar infiltrates and absence of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. In ARDS diffuse injury to pulmonary microvascular endothelium or alveolar epithelium results in a leaky alveolocapillary membrane.In acute stage lungs are heavy,red and boggy. The interstitial and intra alveolar edema,inflammation and fibrin deposition cause alveoli to become lined with waxy hyaline membranes. These membranes consist of fibrous exudates and plasma rich edema fluid mixed with cytoplasmic and lipid remnants and necrotic epithelial cells.These are similar to those seen in hyaline membrane disease of newborn.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - the clinical presentation and raised serum amylase and lipase are indicative otherwise of alveolar hyperinflation. Option C - Intra Alveolar wall destruction - the serum amylase and lipase points towards acute pancreatitis - and so ARDS is more likely - alveolar wall destruction is a late change and will occur in a chronic condition like emphysema. Option D - Common causes of DAH are systemic vasculitis such as WG, CSS, and MPA, Goodpasture's syndrome, CVD, BMT, drugs, and idiopathic conditions. DAH should be suspected in any patient with alveolar infiltrates on chest X-ray, hypoxemia, anemia, and hemoptysis. But this can not be the case with above clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 45 year old man is admitted to ICU with a very complicated UTI.He had symptoms of UTI for the past few months and was left untreated.The patient has very high fever,chills ,disorientation,tachycardia and shortness of breath. Laboratory examination shows a high WBC count and deranged RFT and LFT.Blood culture is positive for infection.The patient condition deteriorates and he develops severe respiratory distress.There are crackles heard bilaterally and chest X Ray shows bilateral infiltrates.What is the characteristic feature of the disease causing respiratory symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse alveolar damage The above clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS that occurred due to sepsis due to complicated UTI. The longstanding untreated UTI has led to sepsis which is evident by the clinical features along with raised total count, deranged RFT and LFT and positive blood culture.Sepsis is a cause of ARDS. Surfactant deficiency occurs in HMD of new born .- Option B. Option A and D - Hypoxemia and hypercapnia - occurs due to block in gaseous exchange which is secondary to diffuse alveolar damage.

Highyeild:

ARDS has 3 phases: exudative, proliferative and fibrotic Exudative : exudative stage during the first 7 to 10 days . There is diffuse Alveolar damage . It is characterized by interstitial edema, acute and chronic inflammation, type II cell hyperplasia, and hyaline membrane formation Proliferative :After approximately 7 to 10 days, a proliferative stage develops, characterized by resolution of pulmonary edema , proliferation of type II alveolar cells , squamous metaplasia , interstitial infiltration by myofibroblasts , and early deposition of collagen . This phase probably lasts for two to three weeks. Fibrotic :characterized by obliteration of normal lung architecture, fibrosis, and cyst formation . The degree of fibrosis ranges from minimal to severe.

questions.text: A 19 year old boy was brought to the ED following a near drowning incident.On arrival,he was unconscious and was not breathing.He was resuscitated and stabilized.A few hours later,he developed sudden onset breathlessness and low saturation. Chest X ray showed diffuse alveolar opacities.He was started on mechanical ventilation.What will be recommended ventilator setting for him?

options.label: A
options.text: Low tidal volume and high PEEP

options.label: B
options.text: Low tidal volume and low PEEP

options.label: C
options.text: High tidal volume and high PEEP

options.label: D
options.text: High tidal volume and low PEEP

questions.correct_answer: A. Low tidal volume and high PEEP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low tidal volume and high PEEP The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ARDS secondary to drowning .The ventilator setting recommended is low tidal volume and high PEEP. Drowning causes direct lung injury.The aspiration of water into lungs damages the surfactant .This disrupts the alveolo-capillary membrane and leads to alveolar edema resulting in ARDS.The ventilator settings recommended are: Low tidal volume:To avoid barotrauma due to overdistension of alveoli. High PEEP: This prevents collapse of alveoli at the end of expiration and improves oxygenation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B , C and D are not the correct options.

questions.text: A 52 year old male patient who is a k/c/o HTN on regular medications presented to ER in severe ARDS due to H1N1 positive bilateral pneumonia on mechanical ventilation in CMV mode.He had a h/o fever,cough shortness of breath,malaise and generalized weakness for 5 days.Initial evaluation revealed bilateral lower lobe consolidation with thrombocytopenia .He was admitted to ICU and treated with prone ventilation .Which of the following has been demonstrated to reduce mortality in patients with ARDS?

options.label: A
options.text: High dose glucocorticoids within 48 hours of presentation

questions.correct_answer: D. Low tidal volume mechanical ventilation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low tidal volume mechanical ventilation The only intervention that decreased mortality in ARDS patient was a low tidal volume mechanical ventilation.T he rationale for this intervention is that overdistension of normal alveoli in patients with ARDS promotes further lung injury.Maintaining a normal or low left atrial filling pressure is recommended.It minimizes pulmonary edema and prevents further decrements in arterial oxygenation and lung compliance.

Similarly ARDS is characterized by surfactant deficiency but administration of exogenous surfactant has not yielded clinical results - Option B - high frequency ventilation is not associated with decrease in mortality.

questions.text: A 24 year old boy is brought to the ED following an RTA in which he had multiple bone fractures.He suddenly developed severe respiratory distress and is suspected of ARDS.Histologic section of lung tissue of this patient is most likely to reveal

options.label: A
options.text: Deposits of needle-like crystals from membranes of eosinophils

options.label: B
options.text: Infiltrating group of malignant cells having intercellular bridges

options.label: C
options.text: Irregular membranes composed of edema,fibrin and dead cells lining alveoli

questions.correct_answer: C. Irregular membranes composed of edema,fibrin and dead cells lining alveoli
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Irregular membranes composed of edema,fibrin and dead cells lining alveoli The patient suffers from ARDS probably due to multiple bone fractures . The most characteristic feature of ARDS is diffuse alveolar damage .This occurs due to injury to the alveolar capillary endothelial cells and type 1 pneumocytes(alveolar epithelial cells) . Edema fluids that is rich in protein accumulates in the interstitial and alveolar spaces.Pro inflammatory cytokines(IL1,IL8 and TNF alpha) and lipid mediators (LTB4)are increased in this acute phase leading to recruitment of leukocytes(esp neutrophils)into pulmonary interstitium and alveoli. In addition condensed plasma proteins aggregate in the air spaces with cellular debris and dysfunctional pulmonary surfactant to form hyaline membrane. Pulmonary vascular injury also occurs early in ARDS with vascular obliteration by microthrombi and fibrocellular proliferation .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Deposits of needle like crystals from membrane of eosinophils is Charcot leyden crystals which is seen in asthma Option B - Infiltrating group of malignant cells with intercellular bridges is seen in squamous cell carcinoma Option D - Plexiform lesions within pulmonary arterioles is a feature of pulmonary hypertension.
